trial_identification.studytitle: A randomised trial of the effectiveness of soft tissue massage in the treatment of shoulder pain
trial_identification.scientifictitle: In patients with non-specific shoulder pain, is soft tissue massage and exercise as good as or better than exercise alone for relief of pain and improvement in shoulder function?

interventions.interventions: Intervention: Soft tissue massage (10 minutes, seven sessions, manual therapy) plus stretching and strengthening exercise (20 minutes, seven sessions, therapist prescribed/patient administered). Treatment received over four week period with no more than one treatment per day (2 treatment sessions per week in weeks 1 to 3, then 1 treatment session only in week 4).
interventions.comparator: Comparator:stretching and strengthening exercise (20 minutes, seven sessions, therapist prescribed/patient administered). Treatment received over four week period with no more than one treatment per day (2 treatment sessions per week in weeks 1 to 3, then 1 treatment session only in week 4).

primaryOutcome.outcome: Change in pain score measured by the Short Form McGill Pain Questionnaire
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Measured at start of treatment, end of treatment sessions (four weeks from start of trial) and three months after cessation of treatment.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Change in functional ability measured by the Shoulder Pain and Disability Index (SPADI)
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Measured at start of treatment, end of treatment sessions (four weeks from start of trial) and three months after cessation of treatment.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Shoulder range of motion as measured by photograph and then protractor.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Measured at start of treatment, end of treatment sessions (four weeks from start of trial) and three months after cessation of treatment.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Referred to physiotherapy for management of shoulder pain * Able to understand spoken English* Both male and female
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Shoulder pain due to trauma in the previous 4 weeks* Shoulder pain is reproduced with any neck movement.* Shoulder pain due to neoplasm* Shoulder pain due to acute inflammatory condition* Other serious pathology* Workers Compensation claim relating to the shoulder pain

trial_design.sequence: Simple randomisation by using a randomisation table from a statistic book

fundingsource.fundingname: Faculty of Health Sciences, University of Sydney.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The experimental hypothesis is that the addition of specific soft tissue massage will improve range of motion and reported function and reduce reported pain. The findings of this study will assist therapists to decide whether to add specific soft tissue massage to a rotator cuff exercise programme when treating patients with shoulder pain of local mechanical origin.
